graph module

Graph module - Modular graph implementation

class gli.graph.BatchOperationContext(graph: Graph)[source]

Bases: object

Context manager for efficient batch operations

__init__(graph: Graph)[source]
add_edge(source: str, target: str, **attributes)[source]

Queue edge for batch addition

add_node(node_id: str | None = None, **attributes)[source]

Queue node for batch addition

set_edge_attributes(edge_attr_dict)[source]

Queue bulk edge attribute updates

Parameters:

edge_attr_dict – Dict mapping (source, target) -> {attr: value}

set_node_attributes(node_attr_dict)[source]

Queue bulk node attribute updates

Parameters:

node_attr_dict – Dict mapping node_id -> {attr: value}

class gli.graph.Graph(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, backend=None, max_auto_states: int = 10, directed: bool = True)[source]

Bases: StateMixin

High-level Graph interface with automatic Rust/Python backend selection

__init__(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, backend=None, max_auto_states: int = 10, directed: bool = True)[source]
add_edge(source: str | int, target: str | int, **attributes) → str[source]

Add an edge to the graph

add_edges(edges_data: List[Dict[str, Any]])[source]

Add multiple edges efficiently in a single operation

Parameters:

edges_data – List of edge dictionaries, each containing ‘source’, ‘target’ and optional attributes

Example

edges = [

{‘source’: ‘user_1’, ‘target’: ‘user_2’, ‘relationship’: ‘manages’}, {‘source’: ‘user_2’, ‘target’: ‘user_3’, ‘relationship’: ‘collaborates’}

] g.add_edges(edges)

add_node(node_id: str | int | None = None, **attributes) → str[source]

Add a node to the graph

add_nodes(nodes_data: List[Dict[str, Any]])[source]

Add multiple nodes efficiently in a single operation

Parameters:

nodes_data – List of node dictionaries, each containing ‘id’ and optional attributes

Example

nodes = [

{‘id’: ‘user_1’, ‘age’: 25, ‘role’: ‘engineer’}, {‘id’: ‘user_2’, ‘age’: 30, ‘role’: ‘manager’}

] g.add_nodes(nodes)

batch_operations()[source]

Context manager for efficient batch operations

property branches

Get current branches from backend (lazy-loaded view)

edge_count() → int[source]

Get the number of edges

property edges

Access edges as a lazy dict-like interface

classmethod empty(backend=None)[source]

Create an empty graph

filter_edges(filter_func: Callable[[str, str | int, str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_graph: bool = False) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter edges by lambda function, attribute values, or string query

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (edge_id, source, target, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “weight > 0.5”

  • return_graph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered edges and connected nodes. If False, return a list of edge IDs (default)

Returns:

List of edge IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_graph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(lambda edge_id, src, tgt, attrs: attrs.get(‘weight’, 0) > 0.5)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’, ‘active’: True})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(“weight > 0.5 and relationship == ‘colleague’”)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’}, return_graph=True)

filter_edges_by_attributes(filters: Dict[str, Any]) → List[str][source]

Legacy alias for filter_edges with attribute dictionary

filter_nodes(filter_func: Callable[[str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_graph: bool = False) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter nodes by lambda function, attribute values, or string query

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (node_id, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “role == ‘Manager’”

  • return_graph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered nodes and their edges. If False, return a list of node IDs (default)

Returns:

List of node IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_graph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(lambda node_id, attrs: attrs.get(‘age’, 0) > 30)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’, ‘department’: ‘Engineering’})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(“role == ‘Manager’ and salary > 100000”)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’}, return_graph=True)

filter_nodes_by_attributes(filters: Dict[str, Any]) → List[str][source]

Legacy alias for filter_nodes with attribute dictionary

classmethod from_edge_list(edges: List[tuple], node_attrs: Dict[str, List[Any]] | None = None, edge_attrs: Dict[str, List[Any]] | None = None, backend=None)[source]

Create graph from edge list (NetworkX-style)

classmethod from_node_list(node_ids: List[str], node_attrs: Dict[str, List[Any]] | None = None, backend=None)[source]

Create graph from vectorized node data (NumPy-style)

get_all_neighbors(node_id: str | int) → List[str][source]

Get all neighbors of a node (both incoming and outgoing)

get_edge(source: str | int, target: str | int) → Edge | None[source]

Get a specific edge by source and target node IDs

get_edge_attributes(source: str | int, target: str | int) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get all attributes of an edge

Parameters:

  • source – Source node ID

  • target – Target node ID

Returns:

Dictionary of edge attributes

get_incoming_neighbors(node_id: str | int) → List[str][source]

Get incoming neighbors of a node (for directed graphs)

get_neighbors(node_id: str | int, direction: str = 'both') → List[str][source]

Get neighbors of a node

Parameters:

  • node_id – The node to get neighbors for

  • direction – ‘out’ for outgoing, ‘in’ for incoming, ‘both’ for all neighbors

get_node(node_id: str | int) → Node | None[source]

Get a specific node by ID

get_node_attributes(node_id: str | int) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get all attributes of a node

Parameters:

node_id – ID of the node

Returns:

Dictionary of node attributes

get_node_ids() → List[str][source]

Get all node IDs

get_outgoing_neighbors(node_id: str | int) → List[str][source]

Get outgoing neighbors of a node (for directed graphs)

node_count() → int[source]

Get the number of nodes

property nodes

Access nodes as a lazy dict-like interface

remove_edge(source: str | int, target: str | int) → bool[source]

Remove an edge from the graph

Parameters:

  • source – Source node ID

  • target – Target node ID

Returns:

Graph Class

The Graph class is the main interface for graph operations in GLI. It provides a high-level Python API backed by a high-performance Rust implementation.

class gli.graph.core.Graph(nodes=None, edges=None, graph_attributes=None, backend=None, max_auto_states: int = 10, directed: bool = True)[source]

Bases: StateMixin

High-level Graph interface with automatic Rust/Python backend selection

filter_edges(filter_func: Callable[[str, str | int, str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_graph: bool = False) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter edges by lambda function, attribute values, or string query

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (edge_id, source, target, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “weight > 0.5”

  • return_graph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered edges and connected nodes. If False, return a list of edge IDs (default)

Returns:

List of edge IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_graph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(lambda edge_id, src, tgt, attrs: attrs.get(‘weight’, 0) > 0.5)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’, ‘active’: True})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(“weight > 0.5 and relationship == ‘colleague’”)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’}, return_graph=True)

filter_edges_by_attributes(filters: Dict[str, Any]) → List[str][source]

Legacy alias for filter_edges with attribute dictionary

filter_nodes(filter_func: Callable[[str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_graph: bool = False) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter nodes by lambda function, attribute values, or string query

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (node_id, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “role == ‘Manager’”

  • return_graph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered nodes and their edges. If False, return a list of node IDs (default)

Returns:

List of node IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_graph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(lambda node_id, attrs: attrs.get(‘age’, 0) > 30)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’, ‘department’: ‘Engineering’})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(“role == ‘Manager’ and salary > 100000”)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’}, return_graph=True)

filter_nodes_by_attributes(filters: Dict[str, Any]) → List[str][source]

Legacy alias for filter_nodes with attribute dictionary

Filtering Operations

Graph.filter_nodes(filter_func: Callable[[str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_graph: bool = False) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter nodes by lambda function, attribute values, or string query

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (node_id, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “role == ‘Manager’”

  • return_graph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered nodes and their edges. If False, return a list of node IDs (default)

Returns:

List of node IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_graph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(lambda node_id, attrs: attrs.get(‘age’, 0) > 30)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’, ‘department’: ‘Engineering’})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_nodes(“role == ‘Manager’ and salary > 100000”)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_nodes({‘role’: ‘Manager’}, return_graph=True)

Graph.filter_edges(filter_func: Callable[[str, str | int, str | int, Dict[str, Any]], bool] | Dict[str, Any] | str = None, return_graph: bool = False) → List[str] | Subgraph[source]

Filter edges by lambda function, attribute values, or string query

Parameters:

  • filter_func – Either a callable that takes (edge_id, source, target, attributes) and returns bool, a dictionary of attribute filters, or a string query like “weight > 0.5”

  • return_graph – If True, return a new Subgraph with filtered edges and connected nodes. If False, return a list of edge IDs (default)

Returns:

List of edge IDs that match the filter, or a new Subgraph instance if return_graph=True

Examples

# Function predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(lambda edge_id, src, tgt, attrs: attrs.get(‘weight’, 0) > 0.5)

# Dictionary predicate filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’, ‘active’: True})

# String query filtered_ids = graph.filter_edges(“weight > 0.5 and relationship == ‘colleague’”)

# Return subgraph subgraph = graph.filter_edges({‘relationship’: ‘friend’}, return_graph=True)

Batch Operation Context

Graph.batch_operations()[source]

Context manager for efficient batch operations

Performance Features

The Graph class automatically selects the best available backend:

  • Rust Backend: High-performance implementation for large graphs

  • Python Backend: Fallback implementation with full feature compatibility

Backend selection can be controlled globally or per-instance:

from gli import Graph, set_backend

# Global backend setting
set_backend('rust')
g1 = Graph()  # Uses Rust backend

# Per-instance backend
g2 = Graph(backend='python')  # Forces Python backend

API Examples

Basic Operations

from gli import Graph

# Create a new graph
g = Graph()

# Add nodes with attributes
g.add_node("alice", age=30, role="engineer")
g.add_node("bob", age=25, role="designer")

# Add edges with attributes
g.add_edge("alice", "bob", relationship="colleague", since=2020)

# Query the graph
print(f"Nodes: {g.node_count()}")
print(f"Edges: {g.edge_count()}")
print(f"Alice's neighbors: {g.get_neighbors('alice')}")

Batch Operations

# Efficient bulk operations
nodes = [
    {'id': 'user_1', 'age': 25, 'role': 'engineer'},
    {'id': 'user_2', 'age': 30, 'role': 'manager'},
    {'id': 'user_3', 'age': 28, 'role': 'designer'}
]
g.add_nodes(nodes)

edges = [
    {'source': 'user_1', 'target': 'user_2', 'relationship': 'reports_to'},
    {'source': 'user_2', 'target': 'user_3', 'relationship': 'manages'}
]
g.add_edges(edges)

Update Operations

# Update single node/edge
g.update_node("alice", age=31, department="engineering")
g.update_edge("alice", "bob", strength=0.8, last_contact="2024-01-15")

# Batch updates
updates = {
    'user_1': {'salary': 80000, 'level': 'senior'},
    'user_2': {'salary': 90000, 'department': 'engineering'}
}
g.update_nodes(updates)

Filtering Operations

# Filter by function
senior_employees = g.filter_nodes(
    lambda node_id, attrs: attrs.get('age', 0) > 30
)

# Filter by attributes
managers = g.filter_nodes({'role': 'manager'})

# Filter by query string
high_earners = g.filter_nodes("salary > 85000 and role == 'engineer'")

# Return subgraph instead of node list
manager_subgraph = g.filter_nodes({'role': 'manager'}, return_graph=True)

Context Manager for Batch Operations

# Use context manager for optimal performance
with g.batch_operations() as batch:
    for i in range(1000):
        batch.add_node(f"node_{i}", value=i)
        if i > 0:
            batch.add_edge(f"node_{i-1}", f"node_{i}", weight=1.0)

    # Bulk attribute updates within context
    node_updates = {f"node_{i}": {"processed": True} for i in range(100)}
    batch.set_node_attributes(node_updates)

Migration from Old API

The following methods have been simplified (removed _bulk suffix):

# Old API (deprecated)
g.add_nodes_bulk(nodes_data)
g.add_edges_bulk(edges_data)
g.update_nodes_bulk(updates)

# New API (recommended)
g.add_nodes(nodes_data)
g.add_edges(edges_data)
g.update_nodes(updates)

The old method names are still supported for backward compatibility but will be removed in future versions.
